memories.title: Context-hub plugin: Manual installation via file copy
memories.content: When the context-hub Claude Code plugin isn't loading properly via marketplace, copy files directly from the GitHub repo (ScottRBK/context-hub-plugin). Copy to `.claude/`: (1) agents/context-retrieval.md, (2) commands/*.md (7 files: context_gather, context-hub-setup, encode-repo-serena, memory-explore, memory-list, memory-save, memory-search), (3) skills/ (5 dirs: curating-memories, exploring-knowledge-graph, serena-code-architecture, using-forgetful-memory, using-serena-symbols). Claude Code must be restarted to pick up new commands.
memories.context: Workaround when plugin marketplace installation fails or plugin doesn't expose tools/skills

memories.title: ai-agents: Multi-platform agent system overview
memories.content: Coordinated multi-agent system for software development with 18 specialized agents. Supports three platforms: Claude Code CLI, GitHub Copilot CLI, and VS Code/GitHub Copilot. Agents are defined in Markdown under src/ with platform-specific variants. Key features: explicit handoff protocols, cross-session memory (Serena + Forgetful), self-improvement via retrospectives. Installation scripts in scripts/ for global or per-repo setup.
memories.context: Foundational understanding of what the ai-agents project is and does

memories.title: ai-agents: 18 specialized agents by category
memories.content: Primary workflow agents: orchestrator (routing), analyst (research), architect (design), planner (decomposition), implementer (code), critic (validation), qa (testing), roadmap (strategy). Support agents: memory (context retrieval), skillbook (skill management), devops (CI/CD), security (threat modeling), independent-thinker (challenge assumptions), high-level-advisor (decisions), retrospective (learning extraction), explainer (documentation), task-generator (task breakdown), pr-comment-responder (PR feedback). Agent definitions in src/claude/, src/copilot-cli/, src/vs-code-agents/.
memories.context: Understanding agent roles for proper routing and invocation

memories.title: ai-agents: Standard workflow patterns
memories.content: Feature development: orchestrator → analyst → architect → planner → critic → implementer → qa → retrospective. Quick fix: implementer → qa. Strategic decision: independent-thinker → high-level-advisor → task-generator. Security-sensitive: analyst → security → architect → critic → implementer → qa. Always start complex tasks with orchestrator for proper routing. Critic validates plans before implementation. QA validates after implementation.
memories.context: Choosing the right workflow for different task types

memories.title: ai-agents: Tech stack and constraints
memories.content: Languages: Markdown (agent definitions), PowerShell only for scripts (ADR-005 - no .sh or .py), YAML (CI workflows - logic in .psm1 not YAML per ADR-006). Tools: markdownlint-cli2 (linting), git hooks (pre-commit validation). Platform: Windows primary, cross-platform compatible. Key constraints: atomic commits (one logical change), use skills from .claude/skills/ before raw gh commands, verification-based enforcement over trust.
memories.context: Technical decisions and hard constraints to follow

memories.title: ai-agents: Memory systems (Serena + Forgetful)
memories.content: Two complementary memory systems: (1) Serena MCP - project-specific memories in .serena/memories/, 350+ memories, LSP-powered symbol analysis, use mcp__serena__* tools. (2) Forgetful MCP - semantic search across projects, knowledge graph with entities, use mcp__forgetful__execute_forgetful_tool. Pattern: Serena for project-specific context and code analysis, Forgetful for cross-project patterns and entity relationships. Memory-first rule: always retrieve context before reasoning.
memories.context: Understanding which memory system to use and when

memories.title: ADR-005: PowerShell-only scripting standard
memories.content: MUST use PowerShell for all scripts (.ps1, .psm1). MUST NOT create bash (.sh) or Python (.py) scripts. Rationale: 100% of existing infrastructure is PowerShell, single testing framework (Pester), cross-platform via PowerShell Core. During PR #60, 829 lines of bash were generated then deleted - wasted tokens. Agents eventually implement in PowerShell anyway. No exceptions - if PowerShell is insufficient, document why and get explicit approval.
memories.context: Critical constraint - prevents token waste on bash/Python that gets deleted

memories.title: ADR-007: Memory-first architecture
memories.content: Memory retrieval MUST precede reasoning in all agent workflows. Step 0 of SESSION-PROTOCOL: call list_memories before analysis. New patterns stored with semantic embeddings. Session logs must evidence memory retrieval before decisions. Inspired by claude-flow's 84.8% SWE-Bench solve rate (vs 43% industry average) attributed to sophisticated memory with HNSW indexing. Without this, agents re-learn same patterns, lose institutional knowledge, behave inconsistently.
memories.context: Foundational architecture pattern - retrieve context before reasoning

memories.title: PROJECT-CONSTRAINTS.md: Single source for hard constraints
memories.content: Canonical source of truth for project constraints. Key constraints: (1) Language: PowerShell only, no .sh or .py (ADR-005). (2) Skills: MUST check .claude/skills/ before GitHub ops, use skills not raw gh commands. (3) Workflows: no business logic in YAML, logic in .psm1 modules (ADR-006). (4) Commits: atomic, one logical change, conventional format. (5) Session: initialize Serena first, read HANDOFF.md, create session log. Location: .agents/governance/PROJECT-CONSTRAINTS.md
memories.context: Read at session start to understand hard constraints

memories.title: ADR-006: Thin workflows, testable modules
memories.content: Workflows orchestrate only; all business logic in PowerShell modules. Pattern: Workflow YAML (orchestration) → PowerShell Module (.psm1, business logic) → Pester Tests (fast local feedback). Rationale: GitHub Actions can't be tested locally. Feedback loop is edit→push→wait 1-5min→check. Extracting logic to modules enables fast local testing (seconds). SHOULD keep workflows under 100 lines. MUST have Pester tests for modules (80%+ coverage).
memories.context: Companion to ADR-005 - enables fast local testing of workflow logic

memories.title: ADR-009: Parallel-safe multi-agent design
memories.content: Multi-agent coordination MUST include consensus mechanisms for conflict resolution. Parallel dispatch: orchestrator can spawn multiple agents for independent concerns. Aggregation strategies: Merge (non-conflicting), Vote (redundant), Escalate (conflicts). Coordination modes: start with Hierarchical (orchestrator-led), evolve to Mesh. Enables 2-4x speedup for multi-agent tasks. Inspired by claude-flow's coordination patterns.
memories.context: Architecture for concurrent agent execution without conflicts

memories.title: ADR-014: Distributed handoff architecture (three-tier)
memories.content: Three-tier system replaces centralized HANDOFF.md: Tier 1 (Session): .agents/sessions/YYYY-MM-DD-session-NN.md (2K tokens, permanent, authoritative). Tier 2 (Branch): .agents/handoffs/{branch}/ (3K, deleted on merge, optional). Tier 3 (Canonical): .agents/HANDOFF.md (5K hard limit, read-only dashboard). Key rule: HANDOFF.md is READ-ONLY on feature branches. Session logs are authoritative. Serena memory for cross-session context. Solved: 35K tokens, 80%+ merge conflict rate, exponential AI review costs.
memories.context: Critical architecture change - session logs replace HANDOFF.md for writes

memories.title: Skill creation criteria: Solved vs unsolved problems
memories.content: Core principle: Ask 'Should the LLM do this?' not 'Can it?' Solved problems (known repeatable solutions) → create skill. Unsolved problems (contextual judgment) → LLM direct. Decision matrix: (1) Documented procedure? (2) Failures from skipped steps? (3) Fixed output format? (4) Repeats >3x/week? (5) Programmatically verifiable? If ≥3 yes, create skill. Examples: git ops, PR creation, session protocol = skills. Architecture decisions, code review, bug diagnosis = LLM.
memories.context: Governance for when to create skills vs let LLM handle directly

memories.title: Agent interview protocol: 8 standardized questions
memories.content: Protocol for discovering and documenting agent capabilities. 8 questions: (1) Core specialty (one sentence), (2) Specific tasks (5-10 examples), (3) Limitations (critical!), (4) Agent pairings, (5) Input requirements, (6) Output format, (7) Success criteria, (8) Failure modes. Use when: new agent creation, significant capability change, routing issues, annual review. Ensures consistent documentation for accurate orchestrator routing.
memories.context: Governance for agent documentation and capability discovery

memories.title: ADR-007 Augmentation: Memory-First Architecture Research
memories.content:
Comprehensive research to augment ADR-007 with modern memory-first patterns from four sources:

**Forgetful MCP**: Meta-tools pattern (3 tools expose 42 operations), dual graph architecture (memory + entity graphs), auto-linking at cosine similarity ≥0.7, token budget management (8000 tokens default), multi-stage retrieval (dense→sparse→RRF→cross-encoder reranking).

**BMAD Method**: Sidecar files for per-agent persistent memory, critical actions enforcing pre-task memory loading, scale-adaptive workflows (Quick/BMad/Enterprise tracks), Party Mode for multi-agent collaboration.

**Zettelkasten**: Atomicity (one concept per note, 300-400 words), unique identifiers for robust cross-referencing, explicit linking with relationship context, emergence of patterns from growing networks.

**A-MEM (arXiv 2502.12110)**: Dynamic memory organization with contextual metadata, intelligent linking based on meaningful similarities, memory evolution where new memories trigger updates to existing attributes, superior improvement over SOTA baselines.
memories.context: Research findings used to augment ADR-007 with modern memory-first architecture patterns. Apply when designing memory systems, implementing knowledge graphs, or evaluating memory retrieval strategies.

memories.title: ADR-007 Enforcement: Claude Code Hooks Implementation
memories.content: Implemented bulletproof enforcement mechanisms for ADR-007 Memory-First Architecture. Created Claude Code hooks infrastructure at .claude/hooks/ with two bash scripts: session-start-memory-first.sh (injects Phase 1/2 blocking gate requirements at session start) and user-prompt-memory-check.sh (detects planning/implementation keywords and injects memory-first reminder). Hooks registered in .claude/settings.json under 'hooks' key with nested structure: hooks -> SessionStart/UserPromptSubmit -> array of { hooks: [{ type: 'command', command: '...' }] }. Exit code 0 = success with stdout injected as context. Exit code 2 = block action. Issue #729 tracks remaining enforcement work (E2: session validation, E4: pre-commit evidence check, E5: Forgetful CI verification). skill-usage-mandatory memory also created in Serena to fill referenced but missing memory gap.
memories.context: Use when implementing or debugging Claude Code hooks, understanding ADR-007 enforcement mechanisms, or continuing work on Issue #729

memories.title: ADR-005 Violation: Always Use PowerShell, Never Bash Scripts
memories.content: Made a mistake creating .sh bash scripts for Claude Code hooks when ADR-005 explicitly mandates PowerShell only (.ps1/.psm1). This project has a hard constraint: MUST use PowerShell only - no .sh or .py files allowed. The violation response is immediate correction. When implementing any scripting in this project, always use PowerShell Core (pwsh) which works cross-platform on Windows, macOS, and Linux. For Claude Code hooks, the command format is: pwsh -NoProfile -File "$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR/.claude/hooks/script-name.ps1". This applies to all automation, hooks, and scripting - never default to bash even when it seems simpler.
memories.context: Critical constraint to remember before writing any script in ai-agents project. Check ADR-005 before creating script files.

memories.title: ai-agents Project Mission and Goals
memories.content:
The ai-agents repository provides a coordinated multi-agent system for software development across three platforms: Claude Code CLI, GitHub Copilot CLI, and VS Code Copilot.

Core mission: Enable specialized agents to handle different development responsibilities with explicit handoff protocols and persistent memory.

Key goals:
1. Agent specialization - 18 agents with distinct expertise (orchestrator, analyst, architect, planner, implementer, critic, qa, etc.)
2. Cross-session continuity - Memory-first architecture using Serena (project-specific) and Forgetful (semantic search)
3. Verification-based enforcement - Blocking gates ensure protocol compliance
4. Multi-platform support - Shared templates generate Copilot platforms, Claude agents maintained separately
5. Quality gates - Automated validation with AI reviewers, session protocol checks, and traceability verification

Repository structure:
- .agents/ - System artifacts (ADRs, sessions, planning, governance)
- .claude/ - Claude Code configuration (skills, hooks, commands)
- .serena/ - Project-specific memories (472 files)
- src/ - Agent prompts by platform
- scripts/ - PowerShell automation
- templates/ - Shared agent templates
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory establishing project purpose and structure

memories.title: ai-agents Development Setup and Workflow
memories.content:
Development setup requirements and standard workflows for the ai-agents repository.

**Prerequisites:**
1. PowerShell 7+ (cross-platform)
2. Claude Code CLI installed
3. Serena MCP plugin active
4. Forgetful MCP server running (localhost:8020)
5. GitHub CLI (gh) configured
6. Node.js for markdown linting (npx markdownlint-cli2)

**Initial Setup:**
1. Clone repository
2. Activate Serena: mcp__serena__activate_project
3. Load initial instructions: mcp__serena__initial_instructions
4. Read .agents/HANDOFF.md for project status
5. Read .agents/SESSION-PROTOCOL.md for requirements
6. Verify branch before any git operations

**Standard Workflows:**

Feature Development:
analyst -> architect -> planner -> critic -> implementer -> qa -> retrospective

Quick Fix:
implementer -> qa

Strategic Decision:
independent-thinker -> high-level-advisor -> task-generator

Security-Sensitive:
analyst -> security -> architect -> critic -> implementer -> qa

**Session Protocol:**
- Session Start: MUST complete Serena activation, read HANDOFF.md, create session log, list skills, read usage-mandatory memory
- Session End: MUST complete session log, update Serena memory, run markdown linting, route to qa agent (if needed), commit all changes
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory documenting development environment and workflows

memories.title: ai-agents Core Architecture Patterns
memories.content:
Key architectural patterns and design principles governing the ai-agents system.

**Memory-First Architecture (ADR-007):**
- Memory retrieval precedes multi-step reasoning
- Two-tier system: Serena (lexical, project-specific) + Forgetful (semantic, cross-project)
- Memory Router provides unified search with Serena-first routing
- Enforced via Claude Code hooks at session start

**Distributed Handoff Architecture (ADR-014):**
- Three-tier state system: Session logs (authoritative) -> Serena memories (cross-session) -> Forgetful (semantic)
- HANDOFF.md is read-only dashboard, not updated during sessions
- Session logs capture full context in .agents/sessions/YYYY-MM-DD-session-NN.md
- Eliminates 80% merge conflict rate from centralized handoff updates

**Agent Orchestration Patterns:**
- Orchestrator-led dispatch for complex tasks
- Explicit handoff protocols between agents
- Agent outputs to .agents/ subdirectories (analysis/, architecture/, planning/, qa/, etc.)
- Clear routing heuristics by task type

**Verification-Based Enforcement:**
- Blocking gates at session start/end
- Pre-commit hooks validate session protocol compliance
- CI/CD quality gates: AI reviewers, session validation, traceability checks
- RFC 2119 keywords (MUST/SHOULD/MAY) for requirement clarity

**Thin Workflows, Testable Modules (ADR-006):**
- Logic in PowerShell .psm1 modules, not YAML workflows
- Workflows orchestrate, modules implement
- Enables Pester testing of business logic
- Separation of concerns between CI orchestration and implementation
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory documenting core architectural patterns

memories.title: ai-agents Testing Strategy and Quality Gates
memories.content:
Testing approach and quality validation mechanisms for the ai-agents repository.

**Testing Framework:**
- Pester (PowerShell testing framework) for all .ps1/.psm1 modules
- Test files: .Tests.ps1 suffix in scripts/ directory
- Cross-platform testing (Windows, Linux, macOS)
- Test isolation via git worktrees for parallel execution

**Testing Patterns:**
- Unit tests for module functions (Pester Describe/Context/It blocks)
- Integration tests for GitHub API interactions (mocked via test fixtures)
- Contract testing for agent interfaces
- Parameterized tests for multiple scenarios (Pester -TestCases)
- Discovery phase before implementation (ADR-034)

**Quality Gates (Shift-Left):**

1. Pre-Commit Hooks:
   - Session protocol validation (if session log exists)
   - ADR change detection (triggers adr-review skill)
   - Markdown linting

2. Pre-PR Validation (Validate-PrePR.ps1):
   - Markdown linting
   - PowerShell script analysis (PSScriptAnalyzer)
   - Pester tests
   - Session protocol compliance
   - Template synchronization
   - ADR number validation

3. CI/CD Pipeline:
   - AI Spec Validation (traceability checks)
   - PR Validation (description accuracy, QA reports)
   - AI Quality Gate (6 parallel agents: code-assist, cursor-bot, forgetful-memory, gemini-code-assist, deepwiki-research, memory-update)
   - Session Protocol Validation (deterministic script, not AI-based)

**QA Agent Routing:**
- REQUIRED after feature implementation
- SKIPPED for docs-only changes
- SKIPPED for investigation sessions (ADR-034) with limited artifact staging
- Session logs automatically filtered from QA validation
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory documenting testing and quality practices

memories.title: ai-agents PowerShell Practices and Conventions
memories.content:
PowerShell-specific development practices and conventions enforced in the ai-agents repository.

**PowerShell-Only Constraint (ADR-005):**
- All automation scripts MUST be .ps1 or .psm1
- No bash (.sh) or Python (.py) files allowed
- Cross-platform compatibility via PowerShell 7+
- Rationale: Single language reduces cognitive load, improves testability

**Module Structure:**
- .psm1 modules contain reusable functions
- .ps1 scripts are entry points or one-off utilities
- Export-ModuleMember for public API control
- Set-StrictMode -Version Latest for error detection
- $ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop' for fail-fast behavior

**Coding Standards:**
- Comment-Based Help (synopsis, description, examples, parameters)
- Parameter validation ([ValidateSet], [ValidateRange], [ValidatePattern])
- OutputType attributes for type safety
- CmdletBinding for advanced function features
- Explicit return types in PSCustomObject construction

**Common Patterns:**
- GitHub CLI integration via `gh` commands (JSON output piped to ConvertFrom-Json)
- Error handling with try/catch and Write-Warning for degraded states
- Verbose logging with Write-Verbose for debugging
- Array safety: Always use @() for potentially single-element arrays
- String interpolation with double quotes, escape with backticks
- Hash table construction with ordered @{} syntax

**Skills-First Mandate:**
- Before using raw `gh` commands, check .claude/skills/github/scripts/ for existing skills
- Skills provide validated, reusable abstractions over GitHub CLI
- Categories: PR operations, issue operations, reactions, workflow management
- Violation = protocol failure, requires acknowledgment

**Testing Conventions:**
- Pester tests use Describe/Context/It structure
- BeforeAll/BeforeEach for setup
- AfterAll/AfterEach for cleanup
- Mock external dependencies (gh commands, Invoke-RestMethod)
- Test isolation via -Scope parameter
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory documenting PowerShell development practices

memories.title: ai-agents Skill System Architecture
memories.content:
The skill system provides reusable, validated abstractions for common development tasks in the ai-agents repository.

**Skill Categories:**

1. GitHub Operations (.claude/skills/github/scripts/):
   - PR operations: Get-PRContext, New-PR, Merge-PR, Get-PRChecks, Get-PRReviewThreads, Resolve-PRReviewThread
   - Issue operations: New-Issue, Set-IssueLabels, Get-IssueContext
   - Reactions: Add-CommentReaction
   - Workflow management: gh workflow commands

2. Agent Orchestration:
   - adr-review: Multi-agent ADR debate (6 agents, consensus protocol)
   - analyze: Codebase analysis orchestration
   - planner: Interactive planning and execution
   - skillcreator: Meta-skill for creating new skills
   - encode-repo-serena: Repository encoding into Forgetful (12 phases)

3. Quality and Validation:
   - session-log-fixer: Session protocol validation failure diagnosis
   - incoherence: Detect documentation/code drift
   - doc-sync: Synchronize CLAUDE.md indexes

4. Memory Management:
   - memory-search, memory-save, memory-explore, memory-list
   - Context Hub integration (Forgetful MCP + prerequisites)

**Skills-First Mandate (usage-mandatory):**
- MUST check .claude/skills/ directory before using raw commands
- Existing skill use is REQUIRED (no inline reimplementation)
- Missing skills MUST be added to library, not written inline
- Violation = session protocol failure

**Skill Structure:**
- SKILL.md: Documentation with Quick Start, usage examples, references
- scripts/: PowerShell implementation (.ps1/.psm1)
- references/: Extended documentation for token efficiency
- Skill invocation via Skill tool: Skill(skill="skill-name", args="...")

**Design Principles:**
- Token efficiency: Core instructions in SKILL.md, details in references/
- Self-contained: Skills include all necessary context
- Validated: Error handling with explicit failure modes
- Reusable: Abstract patterns, not one-off scripts
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1 - Foundation memory documenting the skill system architecture

memories.title: ai-agents External Dependencies and MCP Integration
memories.content:
External dependencies and Model Context Protocol (MCP) server integration for the ai-agents repository.

**MCP Servers:**

1. Serena MCP (stdio transport):
   - Purpose: Code analysis, project memory, symbol lookup, LSP-powered analysis
   - Activation: mcp__serena__activate_project at session start
   - Key Operations: list_memories, read_memory, write_memory, find_symbol, get_project_context
   - Memory Location: .serena/memories/ (472+ markdown files)
   - Project Configuration: .serena/project.yml
   - Required: YES (blocking gate at session start)

2. Forgetful MCP (HTTP transport, localhost:8020/mcp):
   - Purpose: Semantic search, knowledge graph, cross-project patterns
   - Tool Count: 38 tools across 6 categories (user, memory, project, code_artifact, document, entity)
   - Key Features: Auto-linking (cosine similarity ≥0.7), entity relationships, dual graph (memory + entity)
   - Installation: claude mcp add forgetful --scope user -- uvx forgetful-ai
   - Health Check: Test-ForgetfulHealth.ps1 (Note: current bug with Accept header, use MCP framework directly)
   - Required: NO (optional augmentation for Memory Router)

3. DeepWiki MCP (HTTP transport, mcp.deepwiki.com/mcp):
   - Purpose: Documentation lookup for frameworks and libraries
   - Required: NO (optional for research)

**GitHub Dependencies:**
- GitHub CLI (gh): ALL GitHub operations use gh commands, not REST API directly
- GraphQL API: Used for merge state verification (source of truth over gh pr view)
- REST API: Used for review thread resolution, comment operations
- Required: YES (core workflow dependency)

**Node.js Dependencies:**
- markdownlint-cli2: Markdown linting (npx markdownlint-cli2 --fix)
- Required: YES (session end blocking gate)

**PowerShell Dependencies:**
- PowerShell 7+: Cross-platform scripting runtime
- Pester: Testing framework
- PSScriptAnalyzer: Static analysis for quality gates
- Required: YES (ADR-005 constraint)
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 1B - Dependencies memory documenting external integrations

memories.title: Memory Router Module Architecture (MemoryRouter.psm1)
memories.content:
The Memory Router provides unified memory search across Serena (lexical) and Forgetful (semantic) backends, implementing ADR-037 Memory Router Architecture for Phase 2A.

**Public API (3 functions):**

1. Search-Memory:
   - Main entry point for unified search
   - Parameters: Query (validated pattern), MaxResults (1-100), SemanticOnly, LexicalOnly
   - Routing: Always Serena first (unless SemanticOnly), optionally augments with Forgetful
   - Deduplication: SHA-256 content hashing to identify duplicates
   - Returns: Array of PSCustomObject with Name, Content, Source, Score, Path/Id, Hash

2. Test-ForgetfulAvailable:
   - TCP health check to localhost:8020
   - 30-second caching to minimize overhead (script:HealthCache)
   - Timeout: 500ms for connection check
   - Returns: Boolean availability status

3. Get-MemoryRouterStatus:
   - Diagnostic information about router state
   - Reports: Serena availability (path check), Forgetful availability (cached), cache age, configuration
   - Returns: PSCustomObject with Serena, Forgetful, Cache, Configuration properties

**Private Functions (4 helpers):**

1. Get-ContentHash: SHA-256 hashing for deduplication
2. Invoke-SerenaSearch: Lexical search via .serena/memories/ directory scan, keyword matching in filenames, percentage-based scoring
3. Invoke-ForgetfulSearch: JSON-RPC 2.0 call to http://localhost:8020/mcp, tools/call method with memory_search tool
4. Merge-MemoryResults: Deduplicate using hash, Serena takes priority (canonical source), limit to MaxResults

**Configuration:**
- SerenaPath: .serena/memories (default)
- ForgetfulPort: 8020 (default)
- ForgetfulTimeout: 500ms
- MaxResults: 10 (default)

**Error Handling:**
- Graceful degradation: Falls back to Serena-only if Forgetful unavailable
- Warning messages for failures (Write-Warning, not throw)
- Validation: Query pattern ^[a-zA-Z0-9\s\-.,_()&:]+$, length 1-500

**Location:** .claude/skills/memory/scripts/MemoryRouter.psm1 (525 lines)
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 2 - Symbol analysis memory documenting Memory Router module

memories.title: Reflexion Memory Module Architecture (ReflexionMemory.psm1)
memories.content:
Implements ADR-038 for episodic replay and causal reasoning as Tiers 2-3 of the four-tier memory system.

**Tier Architecture:**
Tier 0: Working (context), Tier 1: Semantic (Serena+Forgetful), Tier 2: Episodic, Tier 3: Causal

**11 Public Functions:**

Episodes (4): Get-Episode (by ID), Get-Episodes (query with Outcome/Task/Since filters), New-Episode (create from session), Get-DecisionSequence (extract chain)

Causal Graph (3): Add-CausalNode (decision point), Add-CausalEdge (causality link with strength/confidence), Get-CausalPath (traversal)

Patterns (3): Add-Pattern (recurring), Get-Patterns (success), Get-AntiPatterns (failure)

Status (1): Get-ReflexionMemoryStatus (diagnostics)

**Storage:**
- Episodes: .agents/memory/episodes/episode-*.json
- Causal Graph: .agents/memory/causality/causal-graph.json
- Schemas: .claude/skills/memory/resources/schemas/

**Key Features:**
- JSON Schema validation via PowerShell 7 Test-Json
- Fail-loud for missing schemas (FileNotFoundException)
- Graceful degradation for corrupted files (skip with warning)
- Episode filters: outcome (success/partial/failure), task substring, date range
- Causal graph: nodes (decisions), edges (causality with strength), patterns (recurring behaviors)

**Error Handling:** Permission errors logged, corrupted files skipped with count reported

**Location:** .claude/skills/memory/scripts/ReflexionMemory.psm1
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 2 - Symbol analysis memory for Reflexion Memory module

memories.title: GitHub Skills Pattern and Architecture
memories.content:
GitHub operations in ai-agents follow a consistent skills-first pattern with validated abstractions over GitHub CLI.

**Skills Categories:**
1. PR Operations: Get-PRContext, New-PR, Merge-PR, Get-PRChecks, Get-PRReviewThreads, Get-UnresolvedReviewThreads, Get-UnaddressedComments, Post-PRCommentReply, Resolve-PRReviewThread, Test-PRMerged
2. Issue Operations: New-Issue, Set-IssueLabels, Get-IssueContext, Add-IssueComment
3. Reactions: Add-CommentReaction (thumbsup, thumbsdown, laugh, hooray, confused, heart, rocket, eyes)
4. Workflow: gh workflow run with --ref flag enforcement

**Common Pattern:**
- Import GitHubCore.psm1 module
- Assert-GhAuthenticated (fail-fast if not logged in)
- Resolve-RepoParams (infer Owner/Repo from git remote or params)
- Call gh CLI with JSON output (--json flag)
- Parse with ConvertFrom-Json
- Return PSCustomObject with Success flag + data
- Exit codes: 0=Success, 1=Invalid params, 2=Not found, 3=API error, 4=Not authenticated

**Get-PRContext Key Features:**
- Retrieves comprehensive PR metadata (number, title, body, state, author, branches, labels, reviewers, commits, additions, deletions)
- Optional flags: -IncludeDiff, -IncludeChangedFiles, -DiffStat
- Fields queried: mergeable, mergedAt, mergedBy, createdAt, updatedAt
- Returns structured PSCustomObject for parsing

**Branch Verification (CRITICAL):**
- MUST run `git branch --show-current` before mutations
- gh workflow run MUST include --ref {branch}
- gh pr create MUST include --base and --head
- Prevents wrong-branch commits (100% of Session 15 wrong-branch errors from missing verification)

**Skills-First Mandate Enforcement:** Check .claude/skills/github/scripts/ before using raw gh commands. Violation = protocol failure.

**Location:** .claude/skills/github/scripts/
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 2 - Pattern memory documenting GitHub skills architecture

memories.title: ADR Review Multi-Agent Debate Protocol
memories.content:
The adr-review skill orchestrates 6 specialized agents through structured debate rounds until consensus for ADR validation.

**Agents (6 total):**
1. architect: Structure, governance, coherence, ADR compliance
2. critic: Gaps, risks, alignment, completeness
3. independent-thinker: Challenge assumptions, contrarian views
4. security: Threat models, security trade-offs
5. analyst: Root cause, evidence, feasibility
6. high-level-advisor: Priority, resolve conflicts, break ties

**Debate Phases (0-4):**
- Phase 0: Related work research (search issues/PRs for context)
- Phase 1: Independent review (each agent reviews ADR separately)
- Phase 2: Consolidation (identify consensus and conflicts)
- Phase 3: Resolution (propose updates for P0/P1 issues)
- Phase 4: Convergence check (vote: Accept/D&C/Block)

**Consensus Requirement:** All 6 agents Accept OR Disagree-and-Commit (D&C). Max 10 rounds.

**Issue Resolution:**
- P0 (BLOCKING): Must resolve before acceptance
- P1 (BLOCKING): Resolve OR defer with GitHub issue
- P2 (Non-blocking): Document only

**Deletion Workflow (D1-D4):**
- D1: Detection (identify deleted ADR)
- D2: Impact assessment (find dependencies)
- D3: Archival decision (archive accepted ADRs)
- D4: Cleanup (update references)

**Triggers:**
- Automatic: Pre-commit hook detects .agents/architecture/ADR-*.md changes
- Manual: User invokes /adr-review or "review this ADR"
- Detection: Detect-ADRChanges.ps1 script

**Outputs:**
- Debate log: .agents/critique/ADR-NNN-debate-log.md
- Updated ADR with status (proposed/accepted/needs-revision)
- Documented P0/P1/P2 issues and resolutions

**Location:** .claude/skills/adr-review/
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 2 - Process memory documenting ADR review orchestration

memories.title: CI/CD Validation Pipeline Architecture
memories.content:
Multi-layer validation pipeline enforces quality gates through shift-left validation and automated AI review.

**Pre-Commit Hooks:**
1. Session protocol validation (if session log exists)
2. ADR change detection (triggers adr-review skill reminder)
3. Markdown linting

**Pre-PR Validation (Validate-PrePR.ps1):**
6 local checks before creating PR:
1. Markdown linting (markdownlint-cli2)
2. PowerShell script analysis (PSScriptAnalyzer)
3. Pester tests
4. Session protocol compliance
5. Template synchronization (agent template → Copilot platforms)
6. ADR number validation (sequential numbering)

**CI/CD Workflows:**

1. AI Spec Validation (ai-spec-validation.yml):
   - Requirements traceability checks
   - PRD/ADR/spec cross-reference validation
   - Enforcement: blocking if requirements missing

2. PR Validation (pr-validation.yml):
   - PR description accuracy (template compliance)
   - QA report existence (if feature implementation)
   - Commit count limits (atomic commit enforcement)
   - Title conventional commit format

3. AI Quality Gate (ai-pr-quality-gate.yml):
   - 6 parallel AI agents review code:
     - code-assist (GitHub Copilot)
     - cursor-bot (Cursor AI)
     - forgetful-memory (memory consistency)
     - gemini-code-assist (Google Gemini)
     - deepwiki-research (documentation lookup)
     - memory-update (Serena memory sync)
   - Infrastructure failure tracking (transient vs code quality)
   - Non-blocking (advisory only)

4. Session Protocol Validation (session-protocol-validation.yml):
   - Deterministic script validation (NOT AI-based)
   - Validates MUST requirements (RFC 2119)
   - Blocking: PR cannot merge if session invalid
   - Script: Validate-SessionProtocol.ps1

**Failure Handling:**
- Infrastructure failures: Note and continue
- Code quality failures: Address or acknowledge
- Session validation failures: Use session-log-fixer skill

**Enforcement Philosophy:** Shift-left + fail-fast + verification-based

**Location:** .github/workflows/
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 2 - Process memory documenting CI/CD validation pipeline

memories.title: Agent Handoff Pattern: Orchestrator-Led Dispatch
memories.content:
Standard pattern for routing complex tasks through specialized agents.

**Flow**: User request → orchestrator → (analyst/architect/planner) → critic → implementer → qa

**Orchestrator Responsibilities**:
- Classify task complexity (simple/medium/complex/epic)
- Route to appropriate specialized agent
- Manage handoffs with explicit context transfer
- Synthesize results from multiple agents

**Handoff Protocol**:
1. Announce next agent and purpose
2. Transfer context (artifacts, decisions, constraints)
3. Specify expected deliverable
4. Route via Task tool with clear prompt

**Example Routing Heuristics**:
- Code implementation → implementer (may skip analyst for simple tasks)
- Architecture decision → analyst → architect → (adr-review skill if ADR created)
- Task decomposition → planner → critic → task-generator
- Security-sensitive → analyst → security → architect

**Output Artifacts**: Agents write to .agents/ subdirectories (analysis/, architecture/, planning/, qa/, etc.)

**Success Pattern**: Explicit handoffs prevent context loss, ensure accountability, enable parallel work when dependencies allow.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for agent orchestration workflows

memories.title: Session Protocol Verification-Based Enforcement Pattern
memories.content:
Blocking gates at session boundaries ensure protocol compliance through mechanized verification.

**Session Start (BLOCKING)**:
1. mcp__serena__activate_project (MUST)
2. mcp__serena__initial_instructions (MUST)
3. Read .agents/HANDOFF.md (MUST)
4. Create session log .agents/sessions/YYYY-MM-DD-session-NN.md (MUST)
5. List skills in .claude/skills/github/scripts/ (MUST)
6. Read usage-mandatory memory (MUST)
7. Read PROJECT-CONSTRAINTS.md (MUST)
8. Verify branch: git branch --show-current (MUST)

**Session End (BLOCKING)**:
1. Complete session log (all sections) (MUST)
2. Update Serena memory for cross-session context (MUST)
3. Run npx markdownlint-cli2 --fix (MUST)
4. Route to qa agent if feature implementation (MUST, unless docs/investigation-only)
5. Commit all changes including .serena/memories/ (MUST)
6. MUST NOT update .agents/HANDOFF.md (read-only per ADR-014)

**Validation**: pwsh scripts/Validate-SessionEnd.ps1 -SessionLogPath "[log].md"

**Enforcement Mechanism**: Pre-commit hooks + CI/CD workflow (session-protocol-validation.yml)

**Success Pattern**: RFC 2119 MUST requirements prevent protocol drift, ensure institutional memory continuity.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for session lifecycle enforcement

memories.title: Atomic Commit Pattern: One Logical Change Per Commit
memories.content:
Conventional commits with single logical changes enable clean history and easy rollbacks.

**Rules**:
- One commit = one logical change (feature, fix, refactor, docs)
- Max 5 files OR single topic (whichever is smaller)
- NO mixing concerns (e.g., feature + unrelated refactor)
- NO partial implementations (commit must be self-contained)

**Conventional Commit Format**:
```
type(scope): short description

Detailed explanation of what/why.

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
```

**Types**: feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, chore, perf, ci, style

**Scope Examples**: planning, memory, agents, skills, ci, docs

**Git Sequence**:
1. Verify branch: git branch --show-current
2. Stage specific files: git add [files]
3. Commit with heredoc message (proper formatting)
4. NO --amend unless: HEAD created in this session, not pushed, pre-commit hook auto-modified files

**Anti-Patterns**:
- Batching multiple unrelated changes
- Committing WIP (work in progress)
- Amending commits after push (requires force push)
- Skipping hooks with --no-verify

**Success Pattern**: Small, focused commits enable git bisect, easy code review, clean cherry-picks.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for commit discipline

memories.title: Branch Verification Before Mutations Pattern
memories.content:
Always verify current branch before git operations to prevent cross-PR contamination.

**REQUIRED Verification**:
```bash
# 1. Verify current branch FIRST
git branch --show-current

# 2. Confirm it matches intended PR/issue
# 3. Then proceed with mutation
```

**Operations Requiring Verification**:
- git commit (any)
- git push
- gh workflow run (MUST include --ref {branch})
- gh pr create (MUST include --base and --head)
- File writes that will be committed

**Why Critical**:
- PR #669 retrospective: 100% of wrong-branch commits from missing verification
- Session 15: Multiple cross-PR contamination incidents
- Cost: Hours of cleanup, force pushes, PR recreation

**Git Worktree Pattern**:
For parallel PR work:
```bash
# Create isolated worktree per PR
git worktree add "../worktree-pr-{number}" "{branch}"
cd "../worktree-pr-{number}"
# All mutations now isolated
```

**Workflow --ref Enforcement**:
```bash
# WRONG (uses default branch)
gh workflow run ci.yml

# CORRECT (explicit branch)
gh workflow run ci.yml --ref feat/my-feature
```

**Success Pattern**: Branch verification is muscle memory, prevents 100% of wrong-branch errors.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for git branch safety

memories.title: Skills-First Mandate Enforcement Pattern
memories.content:
Check for existing skills before using raw CLI commands to prevent inline reimplementation.

**Protocol**:
1. Before any gh command: Check .claude/skills/github/scripts/
2. If skill exists: MUST use skill (violation = protocol failure)
3. If skill missing: Add to library, don't write inline

**Discovery Command**:
```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path ".claude/skills/github/scripts" -Recurse -Filter "*.ps1"
```

**Skill Categories**:
- PR: Get-PRContext, New-PR, Merge-PR, Get-PRChecks, Get-PRReviewThreads, Resolve-PRReviewThread, Test-PRMerged
- Issue: New-Issue, Set-IssueLabels, Get-IssueContext
- Reactions: Add-CommentReaction
- Workflow: gh workflow run patterns

**Why Enforced**:
- Prevents duplicated logic across sessions
- Ensures validated, tested abstractions
- Maintains consistent error handling
- Enables reusability and maintenance

**Violation Examples (Session 15)**:
- Used raw `gh pr view` instead of Get-PRContext.ps1 (5+ instances)
- Inline GraphQL queries instead of existing skills
- Cost: Protocol failure acknowledgment required

**Success Pattern**: Skills library grows with project needs, inline scripts migrate to skills.

**Reference**: usage-mandatory memory (Serena)
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for skills-first discipline

memories.title: Graceful Degradation for External Dependencies
memories.content:
Design services to degrade gracefully when optional dependencies unavailable.

**Pattern**: Required vs Optional Dependencies
- Required: Fail fast with clear error (Serena MCP at session start)
- Optional: Warn and continue with reduced functionality (Forgetful MCP for Memory Router)

**Memory Router Example**:
```powershell
# Always query Serena (required)
$serenaResults = Invoke-SerenaSearch -Query $Query

# Augment with Forgetful if available (optional)
if (Test-ForgetfulAvailable) {
    $forgetfulResults = Invoke-ForgetfulSearch -Query $Query
} else {
    Write-Verbose "Forgetful unavailable, returning Serena-only results"
}

# Merge or return Serena-only
return Merge-MemoryResults -SerenaResults $serenaResults -ForgetfulResults $forgetfulResults
```

**Health Check Caching**:
- Cache availability checks (30s TTL for Forgetful)
- Avoid repeated TCP connections
- Fast path when cached

**Error Handling**:
- Write-Warning for degraded state (not throw)
- Return partial results
- Document degradation in output

**User Experience**:
- System remains functional
- Clear visibility into what's available
- No silent failures

**Success Pattern**: Core functionality works even when augmentation services down.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for resilient service design

memories.title: Test-First Development Pattern (Pester)
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for test-driven development

memories.title: Pre-PR Validation Shift-Left Pattern
memories.content:
Run comprehensive validation locally before creating PRs to catch issues early.

**Validate-PrePR.ps1 Unified Runner**:
Orchestrates 6 local checks before PR creation:
1. Markdown linting (markdownlint-cli2)
2. PowerShell script analysis (PSScriptAnalyzer)
3. Pester tests
4. Session protocol compliance
5. Template synchronization (agent templates)
6. ADR number validation

**Usage**:
```bash
# Run all checks
pwsh scripts/Validate-PrePR.ps1

# Exit code 0 = all passed, ready for PR
# Exit code != 0 = failures, fix before PR
```

**Benefits**:
- Catch lint/test failures before CI (faster feedback)
- Prevent protocol violations (session logs, template sync)
- Reduce CI/CD compute costs
- Enable offline validation

**CI/CD Parallel Validation**:
After PR creation, 4 workflows run in parallel:
1. AI Spec Validation (traceability)
2. PR Validation (description, QA reports)
3. AI Quality Gate (6 AI agents)
4. Session Protocol Validation (deterministic)

**Shift-Left Philosophy**:
"Test early, fail fast, fix cheap"
- Pre-commit: Instant feedback (<1s)
- Pre-PR: Comprehensive local checks (~30s)
- CI/CD: Final gate with external services (~5min)

**Success Pattern**: Most issues caught locally, CI rarely fails.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for quality shift-left

memories.title: Memory-First Retrieval Before Reasoning Pattern
memories.content:
Always retrieve context from memory systems before multi-step reasoning to apply learned patterns.

**ADR-007 Mandate**: Memory retrieval MUST precede reasoning in all agent workflows.

**Session Start Enforcement** (Claude Code hooks):
```
1. mcp__serena__activate_project
2. mcp__serena__initial_instructions  
3. Read .agents/HANDOFF.md
4. List relevant memories from Serena
5. Read task-relevant memories
6. THEN begin analysis/planning
```

**Dual Memory System**:
- **Serena (Tier 1)**: Project-specific, lexical, 472+ files in .serena/memories/
- **Forgetful (Tier 1)**: Cross-project, semantic, knowledge graph with entities

**When to Query**:
- Before designing solutions (check for existing patterns)
- Before implementing (check for known gotchas)
- During debugging (check for similar past issues)
- After task completion (store new learnings)

**Query Patterns**:
```python
# Serena (project-specific)
mcp__serena__read_memory(memory_file_name="[topic]")

# Forgetful (semantic search)
mcp__forgetful__execute_forgetful_tool("query_memory", {
    "query": "[topic]",
    "query_context": "why searching"
})
```

**Success Metrics** (claude-flow):
84.8% SWE-Bench solve rate (vs 43% industry average) attributed to sophisticated memory with HNSW indexing.

**Anti-Pattern**: Agents re-learning same patterns, losing institutional knowledge, behaving inconsistently.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for memory-first architecture application

memories.title: ADR-Driven Architecture Decision Pattern
memories.content:
Document significant technical decisions as ADRs to maintain decision history and rationale.

**When to Create ADR**:
- Technology choice (PowerShell-only, ADR-005)
- Architecture pattern (Memory-First, ADR-007; Distributed Handoff, ADR-014)
- Process change (Session Protocol, thin workflows)
- Constraint adoption (enforcement mechanisms)

**ADR Review Process** (adr-review skill):
6-agent multi-perspective debate until consensus:
1. **architect**: Structure, governance, coherence
2. **critic**: Gaps, risks, alignment
3. **independent-thinker**: Challenge assumptions
4. **security**: Threat models, trade-offs
5. **analyst**: Root cause, evidence, feasibility
6. **high-level-advisor**: Priority, conflict resolution

**Consensus Requirement**: All 6 agents Accept OR Disagree-and-Commit. Max 10 rounds.

**Issue Resolution**:
- P0 (BLOCKING): Must resolve before acceptance
- P1 (BLOCKING): Resolve OR defer with GitHub issue
- P2 (Non-blocking): Document only

**Automatic Triggers**:
- Pre-commit hook detects .agents/architecture/ADR-*.md changes
- Displays reminder to invoke /adr-review
- Claude Code hook at session start detects ADR modifications

**ADR Lifecycle**:
1. Proposed (draft)
2. Under Review (debate in progress)
3. Accepted (consensus reached)
4. Superseded (replaced by newer ADR)
5. Rejected (consensus not to implement)

**Success Pattern**: Decisions are traceable, reversible, with documented rationale.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 3 - Pattern memory for architecture governance via ADRs

memories.title: Critical Feature: Orchestrator Dispatch Workflow
memories.content:
Orchestrator routes complex tasks to specialized agents with explicit handoff protocols.

**Entry Point**: Task tool with subagent_type='orchestrator'

**Workflow**:
1. **Classify Complexity**:
   - Simple: Single file, <50 lines, clear requirements
   - Medium: Multi-file, known pattern, moderate dependencies
   - Complex: New pattern, architectural impact, multi-agent coordination
   - Epic: Multiple features, requires planning breakdown

2. **Route to Specialist**:
   - Research: analyst (root cause, feasibility)
   - Design: architect (ADRs, technical decisions)
   - Planning: planner (milestones, work packages)
   - Validation: critic (stress-test plan before implementation)
   - Implementation: implementer (production code)
   - Testing: qa (test strategy, verification)
   - Learning: retrospective (extract patterns)

3. **Manage Handoffs**:
   - Announce: "Routing to {agent} for {purpose}"
   - Context: Provide artifacts, decisions, constraints
   - Deliverable: Specify expected output
   - Execute: Task(subagent_type="{agent}", prompt="{task}")

4. **Synthesize Results**:
   - Collect outputs from .agents/ subdirectories
   - Integrate findings
   - Report to user with clear next steps

**Standard Workflows**:
- Feature: analyst → architect → planner → critic → implementer → qa
- Quick Fix: implementer → qa
- Strategic: independent-thinker → high-level-advisor → task-generator

**Key Files**: src/claude/orchestrator.md
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 4 - Critical feature memory for orchestrator dispatch

memories.title: Critical Feature: Memory Router Unified Search
memories.content:
Memory Router provides unified interface across Serena (lexical) and Forgetful (semantic) with intelligent routing.

**API**: Search-Memory cmdlet in MemoryRouter.psm1

**Search Modes**:
1. **Default (Hybrid)**: Serena first, augment with Forgetful if available
2. **LexicalOnly**: Serena only (use when Forgetful unavailable or for filename-based search)
3. **SemanticOnly**: Forgetful required (fails if unavailable)

**Routing Logic**:
```powershell
# 1. Always query Serena (canonical source)
$serenaResults = Invoke-SerenaSearch -Query $Query

# 2. Augment with Forgetful if available
if (Test-ForgetfulAvailable) {
    $forgetfulResults = Invoke-ForgetfulSearch -Query $Query
}

# 3. Deduplicate via SHA-256 content hash
return Merge-MemoryResults -SerenaResults $serenaResults -ForgetfulResults $forgetfulResults
```

**Deduplication**: SHA-256 hashing identifies identical content, Serena takes priority

**Scoring**:
- Serena: Percentage of query keywords matching filename
- Forgetful: Cosine similarity from vector embeddings

**Health Check**: 30-second cached TCP check to localhost:8020 (Forgetful)

**Graceful Degradation**: Falls back to Serena-only if Forgetful unavailable (Write-Warning, not throw)

**Key Files**:
- .claude/skills/memory/scripts/MemoryRouter.psm1 (525 lines)
- .claude/skills/memory/scripts/Search-Memory.ps1 (agent interface)

**ADR**: ADR-037 Memory Router Architecture
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 4 - Critical feature memory for Memory Router

memories.title: Critical Feature: Session Lifecycle Management
memories.content:
Structured session protocol with blocking gates ensures consistency and institutional memory.

**Session Log Format**: .agents/sessions/YYYY-MM-DD-session-NN.md

**Start Sequence** (BLOCKING):
1. mcp__serena__activate_project (Serena MCP initialization)
2. mcp__serena__initial_instructions (Load Serena guidance)
3. Read .agents/HANDOFF.md (Project status dashboard)
4. Create session log with frontmatter
5. List skills (.claude/skills/github/scripts/)
6. Read usage-mandatory memory (Skills-first mandate)
7. Read PROJECT-CONSTRAINTS.md (Governance)
8. Verify branch (git branch --show-current)

**Session Log Structure**:
```markdown
---
date: YYYY-MM-DD
session: NNN
type: [implementation|investigation|planning]
issues: [#NNN, #NNN]
prs: [#NNN]
---

# Session NNN: [Title]

## Objective
## Work Completed
## Decisions Made
## Next Steps
## Artifacts Created
```

**End Sequence** (BLOCKING):
1. Complete all session log sections
2. Update Serena memory (cross-session context)
3. Run npx markdownlint-cli2 --fix
4. Route to qa agent (if feature implementation)
5. Commit ALL changes (including .serena/memories/)
6. MUST NOT update HANDOFF.md (read-only per ADR-014)

**Validation**: Validate-SessionEnd.ps1 checks MUST requirements

**Enforcement**: Pre-commit hook + CI workflow (session-protocol-validation.yml)

**Success Pattern**: Session logs are authoritative (Tier 1), HANDOFF.md is dashboard (Tier 3).
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 4 - Critical feature memory for session protocol

memories.title: Critical Feature: GitHub PR Management Skills
memories.content:
Validated PowerShell skills provide reusable abstractions for GitHub PR operations.

**Core Skills** (.claude/skills/github/scripts/pr/):

1. **Get-PRContext.ps1**: Comprehensive PR metadata
   - Fields: number, title, body, state, author, branches, labels, commits, mergeable
   - Options: -IncludeDiff, -IncludeChangedFiles, -DiffStat
   - Exit codes: 0=Success, 1=Invalid params, 2=Not found, 3=API error, 4=Not authenticated

2. **Get-PRChecks.ps1**: CI check status
   - Returns: AllPassing (bool), FailedCount, Checks array with Conclusion/DetailsUrl
   - Conclusion values: SUCCESS, NEUTRAL, SKIPPED, FAILURE, CANCELLED

3. **Get-PRReviewThreads.ps1**: Review comment threads
   - Returns: Thread ID, resolved status, comment content
   - Use with Get-UnresolvedReviewThreads.ps1 for filtering

4. **Resolve-PRReviewThread.ps1**: Mark thread as resolved
   - CRITICAL: Replying does NOT auto-resolve, requires separate GraphQL mutation
   - Input: ThreadId (PRRT_xxx format)

5. **Test-PRMerged.ps1**: Merge state verification
   - GraphQL source of truth (gh pr view can be stale)
   - Exit code 0=not merged, 1=merged
   - Use BEFORE review work to avoid wasted effort

**Common Pattern**:
```powershell
# 1. Get context
$pr = & Get-PRContext.ps1 -PullRequest 123

# 2. Check if merged (GraphQL)
& Test-PRMerged.ps1 -PullRequest 123
if ($LASTEXITCODE -eq 1) { return }

# 3. Get failing checks
$checks = & Get-PRChecks.ps1 -PullRequest 123 | ConvertFrom-Json

# 4. Resolve threads
& Resolve-PRReviewThread.ps1 -ThreadId "PRRT_xxx"
```

**Skills-First**: MUST use these skills instead of raw gh commands.
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 4 - Critical feature memory for GitHub PR skills

memories.title: Design Decision: PowerShell-Only Scripting Standard (ADR-005)
memories.content:
All automation scripts MUST be PowerShell (.ps1/.psm1), no bash or Python allowed.

**Decision**: Adopt PowerShell 7+ as single scripting language for cross-platform automation.

**Rationale**:
1. **Cognitive Load**: Single language reduces context switching, enables deeper expertise
2. **Testability**: Pester framework provides robust testing (Describe/Context/It structure)
3. **Cross-Platform**: PowerShell 7+ runs on Windows, Linux, macOS natively
4. **GitHub CLI Integration**: Excellent JSON parsing with ConvertFrom-Json
5. **Module System**: Clean encapsulation with .psm1, Export-ModuleMember

**Constraints Imposed**:
- NO bash scripts (.sh files)
- NO Python scripts (.py files)
- Agent prompts may reference bash commands for user execution, but automation MUST be PowerShell
- Thin workflows (ADR-006): Logic in .psm1 modules, not YAML

**Trade-offs Accepted**:
- Learning curve for bash-fluent developers
- Verbosity compared to bash (compensated by readability)
- Less common in CI/CD examples (compensated by better testability)

**Enforcement**: Pre-commit hooks, code review

**Exceptions**: NONE. Even simple scripts use PowerShell for consistency.

**Status**: Accepted
**ADR**: .agents/architecture/ADR-005-powershell-only-scripting.md
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 5 - Design decision memory documenting language standardization

memories.title: Design Decision: Distributed Handoff Architecture (ADR-014)
memories.content:
Replace centralized HANDOFF.md updates with distributed session logs to eliminate merge conflicts.

**Problem**: HANDOFF.md grew to 35K tokens with 80%+ merge conflict rate on parallel PRs.

**Decision**: Three-tier distributed handoff system:
- Tier 1 (Authoritative): Session logs at .agents/sessions/YYYY-MM-DD-session-NN.md (2K tokens, permanent)
- Tier 2 (Branch-local): .agents/handoffs/{branch}/ (3K tokens, deleted on merge, optional)
- Tier 3 (Dashboard): .agents/HANDOFF.md (5K hard limit, READ-ONLY on feature branches)

**Key Rules**:
1. HANDOFF.md is READ-ONLY during sessions (no updates)
2. Session logs are authoritative source of session context
3. Serena memory stores cross-session learnings
4. HANDOFF.md updated only on main branch by orchestrator

**Benefits**:
- Eliminates 80% merge conflict rate
- Reduces AI review costs (35K → 2K tokens per session)
- Enables parallel PR work without coordination
- Session logs provide complete audit trail

**Implementation**:
- Pre-commit hook blocks HANDOFF.md updates on feature branches
- Session protocol requires session log creation
- Validate-SessionEnd.ps1 checks session log completeness

**Status**: Accepted
**ADR**: .agents/architecture/ADR-014-distributed-handoff-architecture.md
memories.context: Bootstrap M-009 Phase 5 - Design decision memory documenting handoff architecture change

Key sections: Memory System Modules (MemoryRouter.psm1 with 3 public functions, ReflexionMemory.psm1 with 11 functions across Episodes/Causal/Patterns/Status), GitHub Skills (PR operations, Issue operations, Reactions), Validation Scripts (Validate-SessionEnd.ps1, Test-MemoryHealth.ps1), Shared Modules (GitHub.psm1 with authentication and error handling). All skills follow standardized exit codes (0=success, 1=invalid, 2=not found, 3=API error, 4=permission denied). memories.title: Architecture Reference Document Entry
memories.content: The ai-agents Architecture Reference provides comprehensive documentation of the multi-agent system design. Key sections: Core ADRs (ADR-005 PowerShell-only, ADR-006 Thin workflows, ADR-007 Memory-first, ADR-014 Distributed handoff, ADR-037 Memory Router, ADR-038 Reflexion Memory), Multi-Agent System (18 agents with routing protocols for feature development, quick fixes, strategic decisions, security-sensitive work), Session Protocol (blocking gates at start/end), Skill System (skills-first mandate with exit code standardization), Integration Patterns (MCP servers, GitHub workflows), Performance Characteristics (Memory Router latency, session log token reduction 94%), Security Model (secret detection, authentication, input validation). Document serves as authoritative reference for understanding system architecture and design decisions.
memories.context: Created during Phase 7 of M-009 bootstrap as comprehensive architecture documentation for new contributors and cross-session reference.

memories.title: Knowledge Graph Navigation Guide Entry
memories.content: The Forgetful Knowledge Graph Navigation Guide explains how to query and navigate the semantic memory system for ai-agents. Core concepts: Memories (atomic knowledge units, 200-400 words, auto-linking at cosine similarity ≥0.7), Entities (typed objects with relationships), Relationships (typed connections with strength/confidence), Documents (long-form >300 words). Query patterns cover memory search (with query_context for ranking), entity search (by name/alias), relationship navigation (get_entity_relationships), document retrieval. Graph traversal examples show how to understand Memory Router dependencies, find all agents, explore capabilities. Best practices include importance scale (10=critical ADRs, 9=core modules, 8=features, 7=standard patterns), entity creation with custom_type for Services/Agents/Modules, relationship metadata. Performance tips: cache project_id, use specific queries, leverage query_context, navigate graph vs searching. Integration with Memory Router provides graceful degradation when Forgetful unavailable.

memories.title: Skills-First Mandate: NEVER Use Raw Commands
memories.content:
CRITICAL: NEVER use raw gh commands when a Claude skill exists. Always check .claude/skills/github/scripts/ FIRST. Violation = protocol failure.

Process:
1. CHECK: ls .claude/skills/github/scripts/**/*.ps1
2. USE: If skill exists, use it (Get-PRContext, Post-PRCommentReply, etc.)
3. EXTEND: If missing, add to skill library, don't write inline

Wrong: gh pr view, gh issue create, gh api ...
Correct: .claude/skills/github/scripts/pr/Get-PRContext.ps1

Skill Categories:
- PR: Get-PRContext, Post-PRCommentReply, Get-PRReviewComments, Get-PRReviewers, Resolve-PRReviewThread
- Issue: Get-IssueContext, Post-IssueComment, Set-IssueLabels, Set-IssueMilestone
- Reactions: Add-CommentReaction

Root cause of violations: Habit (default to inline), not checking first, ignoring corrections.

Enforcement: User rejects PRs/commits using raw gh when skill exists.

Related: ADR-005 (PowerShell-only), ADR-006 (thin workflows)

memories.title: Security Pattern: Input Validation First
memories.content:
ALWAYS validate and sanitize inputs before processing.

Strategy:
- Parameterized queries for database access (never string concatenation)
- Allowlists over denylists for input validation
- Type checking before processing

Pattern:
1. Validate input type matches expected
2. Validate input is within allowed values (allowlist)
3. Sanitize/escape if needed for output context
4. Then process

Context: Any code handling external data (user input, API responses, file content).

Source: .agents/security/security-best-practices.md

Atomicity: 88%
memories.context: Security pattern from Serena memory 'security-002-input-validation-first'

memories.title: Protocol Pattern: Verification-Based BLOCKING Gates
memories.content:
Verification-based BLOCKING gates (tool output required) achieve 100% compliance where trust-based guidance fails.

Gate Design Template:
```markdown
## Phase X: [Name] (BLOCKING)
You MUST [action] before [next step]:
1. [Required action 1]
2. [Required action 2]

**Verification**: [Tool output, file exists, etc.]
**If skipped**: [Consequence]
```

Required Elements:
1. BLOCKING keyword
2. MUST language (RFC 2119)
3. Verification method
4. Tool output evidence in transcript
5. Clear consequence if skipped

Comparison:
| Type | Compliance |
|------|------------|
| Verification-based BLOCKING | 100% |
| Trust-based guidance | <50% |

Validated in Session 92: adr-review auto-trigger uses same pattern.

Generalization: BLOCKING gates work when agent signals mandatory next step, orchestrator has detection pattern, and violation consequences are clear.
memories.context: Protocol pattern from Serena memory 'protocol-blocking-gates' - critical for enforcement design

memories.title: Pre-PR Validation Checklist
memories.content:
Before creating PR, complete ALL validation steps locally:

1. Memory/Skill File Naming (ADR-017)
   Files in .serena/memories/ MUST NOT start with 'skill-' prefix. Use {domain}-{description} format.

2. Pester Tests
   Invoke-Pester -Path 'tests/*.Tests.ps1' -PassThru
   All tests MUST pass.

3. Script Syntax Validation
   All .ps1 files must parse without errors.

4. Style Guide Compliance
   Use $ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop' (not 'SilentlyContinue').

5. Markdown Linting
   npx markdownlint-cli2 --fix "**/*.md"
   WARNING: Do NOT run on .ps1 files (corrupts #> to # >).

PR #730 Root Cause:
| Failure | Cause | Prevention |
|---------|-------|------------|
| Memory validation | skill- prefix | Check ADR-017 |
| Pester fail | PSGallery firewall | Infra issue |
| Style violation | SilentlyContinue | Style guide |
| Parse error | Linting .ps1 | Don't lint .ps1 |
memories.context: Validation checklist from Serena memory 'validation-pre-pr-checklist'

memories.title: Test-First Development Pattern (Pester)
memories.content:
Create Pester tests DURING implementation (not after) for 100% pass rates before commit.

Pattern: Write Test -> Write Code -> Run Test -> Refactor -> Commit

Step 1: Write test (expected behavior)
Step 2: Write minimal code to pass
Step 3: Run Invoke-Pester
Step 4: Refactor with real logic
Step 5: Commit with all tests passing

Coverage Targets:
| Type | Target |
|------|--------|
| Operations | 100% |
| Parameters | 100% |
| Validation | 100% |
| Pass rate | 100% |

Anti-Pattern: Test-After Development
1. Write all code
2. Commit
3. Maybe write tests later
4. Discover bugs in committed code

Benefits:
- Confidence: 100% pass before commit
- Design: Tests force clear API
- Coverage: Natural coverage
- Regression: Prevent future breakage
- Documentation: Tests show usage

Session 21: Check-SkillExists.ps1 (67 lines) + 13 tests = 100% pass on first run.

memories.title: Git Pattern: Branch Verification Before Commit
memories.content:
MUST run `git branch --show-current` before ANY mutating git operation.

Pattern:
1. ALWAYS verify current branch first: git branch --show-current
2. Confirm output matches intended PR/issue branch (feat/issue-XXX)
3. If mismatch: STOP - do not proceed
4. Only after verification, proceed with operation

Why: PR #669 analysis showed 100% prevention of wrong-branch commits when enforced.

Anti-Patterns:
- Assume you're on the right branch
- Skip verification for 'quick' commits
- Trust previous branch switches without re-verification

Related:
- git-hooks-004-branch-name-validation: Pre-commit hook
- session-init-003-branch-declaration: Session tracking
- protocol-013-verification-based-enforcement: Design principle

Atomicity: 92% | Impact: 10/10 (CRITICAL)

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence: Core Principle
memories.content:
Chesterton's Fence is a principle of epistemic humility: 'Do not remove a fence until you know why it was put up.' Origin: G.K. Chesterton's 1929 essay 'The Thing.'

Core insight: The burden of proof lies with the reformer, not the status quo. Just because YOU don't understand why something exists doesn't mean it's useless. It may mean you lack historical context, haven't experienced the problem it solves, or don't see the invisible work it's doing.

Decision rule: Before removing or changing an existing structure, you must (1) understand why it exists, (2) understand what problem it solves, (3) understand what breaks if you remove it, (4) only then decide whether to remove/modify/preserve it.

Philosophical foundation: Recognizes that individual knowledge is limited compared to accumulated institutional knowledge. Complexity often has reasons that aren't immediately obvious.

Key heuristic: If you can't explain to the original builder why they put the fence there, you're not ready to remove it yet.
memories.context: Deep analysis of Chesterton's Fence principle for application to ai-agents project, particularly for preventing changes to existing systems without understanding historical rationale

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence: Four-Phase Decision Framework
memories.content:
Four-phase framework for applying Chesterton's Fence to system changes:

Phase 1 - Investigation (BLOCKING): (1) Document what exists and current function, (2) Research historical origin and original purpose (git blame, PR search), (3) Identify who built it and what problem it solved, (4) Map dependencies (what relies on this?), (5) Trace consequences (what breaks if removed?). Deliverable: Investigation report.

Phase 2 - Understanding (MUST complete): (1) Can you articulate original rationale? (2) Does original problem still exist? (3) Have conditions changed to invalidate solution? (4) What unintended functions has it acquired? Verification: Can you explain to original author why they built it?

Phase 3 - Evaluation (Only after 1-2): (1) Is original problem better solved another way now? (2) Do costs of keeping exceed benefits? (3) Can you mitigate removal risks? (4) What's reversibility cost if you're wrong?

Phase 4 - Action (Conditional): REMOVE if you fully understand it AND problem is obsolete. MODIFY if core function valid but implementation suboptimal. PRESERVE if you don't fully understand (default). REPLACE if poorly designed but you have better solution with migration plan. DOCUMENT always.
memories.context: Structured decision framework for evaluating changes to existing systems, ensuring investigation precedes judgment

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence in Software Engineering
memories.content:
Application of Chesterton's Fence to software development:

**Code complexity**: Before refactoring 'ugly' code, use git blame to find when added, read PR discussion about problem being solved, check tests for edge cases this complexity handles. Anti-pattern: 'This code is ugly, I'll rewrite it' → reintroduces bugs the original code prevented.

**Architecture decisions**: Before proposing monorepo→polyrepo (or vice versa), investigate why current structure exists. Was it chosen for dependency management? Build consistency? Code sharing? What breaking changes has it prevented?

**Protocols and processes**: Before removing mandatory code review, investigate: Why was it mandated? What incidents led to this? What failure modes does it prevent? Then propose alternatives.

**Constraints**: Before relaxing coding standards (like 'no nested ternaries'), search history for bugs it prevented, find PR that added rule, understand readability problems.

Real-world examples: Unix 'everything is a file' (enables powerful composition), QWERTY keyboard (network effects matter), null references (represents real domain concept despite crashes).

Key insight: Long-surviving systems (Lindy Effect) have proven worth through survival. Burden of proof increases with age.
memories.context: Practical application of Chesterton's Fence to software engineering decisions, with concrete examples and anti-patterns

memories.title: Memory-First as Chesterton's Fence Implementation
memories.content:
Memory-first architecture (ADR-007) implements Chesterton's Fence principle for AI agents.

**Translation**: Do not change code/architecture/protocol until you search memory for why it exists.

**Why it works**: Chesterton's Fence requires investigation of historical context before changes. Memory system provides that context: Tier 1 (semantic facts, patterns, constraints), Tier 2 (episodic past session outcomes), Tier 3 (causal decision patterns).

**Concrete prevention**: (1) ADR-037 P0-3 recursion guard - searching memory for 'git hooks call git commands' would reveal pattern absence, triggering investigation. (2) Skills-first violations - searching memory for 'why skills exist' finds testability/consistency rationale. (3) Session protocol drift - searching for 'BLOCKING gates' finds evidence of <50% compliance before enforcement, 100% after.

**Investigation protocol**: Before changes, MUST run Search-Memory.ps1 with relevant query. Memory contains git archaeology (ADRs, incident reports, past attempts, failure episodes, success patterns).

**Enforcement**: Memory-first gate is BLOCKING (same pattern as session protocol) - session logs must show memory search BEFORE decisions. Guidance achieves <50% compliance, BLOCKING gates achieve 100%.

**Key principle**: Memory IS the investigation tool Chesterton's Fence requires.
memories.context: Connection between memory-first architecture and Chesterton's Fence principle, showing how memory search implements the investigation requirement

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence: Common Failure Modes
memories.content:
Seven common failures when ignoring Chesterton's Fence:

1. **'I don't understand it, so it's stupid'**: Assuming complexity is unnecessary rather than investigating purpose. Prevention: Default to 'I don't understand this YET.'

2. **Chronological snobbery**: Assuming newer = better. Example: 'Rewrite in microservices' without understanding why monolith exists. Prevention: Evaluate on merits, not age.

3. **Hindsight bias**: Judging past decisions with present knowledge, ignoring historical constraints. Example: 'They should have used Kubernetes' when it didn't exist. Prevention: Understand what tools/knowledge were available then.

4. **Optimism bias**: Underestimating complexity, overestimating solution quality. Example: 'I'll rewrite this spaghetti code in 2 weeks' → 6 months later, still broken. Prevention: Existing fence survived because it works.

5. **'Original author was an idiot'**: Attributing design to incompetence vs. constraints. Example: 'Why XML not JSON?' → JSON spec didn't exist. Prevention: Assume competence.

6. **'Nobody uses this anymore'**: Removing 'unused' features that are critical but rare. Example: Deprecating API endpoint breaks disaster recovery script. Prevention: Hyrum's Law - if observable, someone depends on it.

7. **'Let's just try it'**: A/B testing removal without understanding what it prevents. Example: Remove rate limiting in experiment → DDoS yourself. Prevention: Some fences prevent catastrophes, not gradual issues.
memories.context: Catalog of common mistakes when ignoring Chesterton's Fence principle, with prevention strategies for each failure mode

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence Decision Matrix for ai-agents
memories.content:
Risk-based matrix for determining investigation depth in ai-agents project:

**CRITICAL risk (Full 4-phase investigation + ADR amendment)**:
- Remove ADR constraint (PowerShell-only, thin workflows, etc.)
- Bypass core protocols (skills-first, BLOCKING gates, memory-first)

**HIGH risk (Phase 1-2 investigation + written justification)**:
- Delete >100 lines of code
- Modify core protocol (session, handoff, validation)
- Change GitHub workflow structure

**MEDIUM risk (Understand edge cases, check test coverage)**:
- Refactor complex code
- Change agent prompts (understand what behaviors they enforce)
- Modify steering files

**LOW risk (Minimal investigation)**:
- Add new validation
- Documentation improvements (but verify accuracy)
- Fix obvious bugs (unless 'bug' might be feature)

**Risk escalation factors**: Code age (>6 months), absence of tests, critical path (failure affects core functionality), security-sensitive, public API (external dependencies).

**Existing fences in ai-agents**: PowerShell-only (ADR-005: Windows support), Skills-first (usage-mandatory: testability), BLOCKING gates (SESSION-PROTOCOL: 100% compliance), Memory-first (ADR-007: learning from history), Atomic commits (code-style: easier rollback), Branch verification (git-004: prevents cross-PR contamination), No logic in YAML (ADR-006: enables testing), Session logs (ADR-014: vs. 80% merge conflicts).
memories.context: Practical decision matrix for applying Chesterton's Fence investigation requirements to different change types in the ai-agents project

memories.title: Chesterton's Fence: Relationship to Other Principles
memories.content:
How Chesterton's Fence relates to other software principles:

**Second System Effect (Brooks)**: When rebuilding, architects over-engineer because they 'learned' from first system's 'mistakes.' Chesterton correction: Before labeling features as mistakes, understand why they exist. Some warts are scars from battle-tested edge cases.

**YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It)**: Don't add functionality until needed. Relationship: YAGNI prevents speculative complexity (don't add fences preemptively). Chesterton prevents regrettable simplification (don't remove existing fences). Both fight complexity from opposite directions.

**Boy Scout Rule**: Leave code cleaner than you found it. Potential conflict: Might encourage removing 'ugly' code that's necessary. Resolution: Chesterton is meta-rule - understand first, then improve.

**Hyrum's Law**: With sufficient users, every observable behavior will be depended upon. Relationship: Explains WHY Chesterton matters in software. That 'unused' API endpoint? Someone uses it. Implication: Even if you can't find why fence was built, assume someone depends on it.

**Defensive Programming**: Add checks/guards against unexpected inputs. Relationship: Creates fences (validation, error handling). Chesterton says don't remove guards without understanding what attacks they defend against.

**Lindy Effect**: Longer something has survived, more likely to continue surviving. Implication: 50-year-old practice has proven worth. Burden of proof increases with age.
memories.context: Synthesis showing how Chesterton's Fence principle relates to and complements other well-known software engineering principles
memories.keywords: ["software principles", "yagni", "second system effect", "hyrums law", "defensive programming", "lindy effect"]

memories.title: Dan North: Evidence-Based Testing Definition
memories.content:
Dan North defines testing with precision: "You are testing if and only if you are increasing confidence for stakeholders through evidence."

Three-part framework:
1. **Stakeholders**: Anyone affected directly or indirectly by the work (developers, users, compliance, security, ops)
2. **Confidence**: Understanding what stakeholders care about and how work impacts those things
3. **Evidence**: Incontrovertible information or data (not opinions, assumptions, or coverage percentages)

Key insight: "The purpose of testing is to increase confidence for stakeholders through evidence."

Implications:
- Test theater doesn't count (running tests that don't produce evidence wastes time)
- Different stakeholders need different evidence (security cares about threats, not line coverage)
- Manual testing is legitimate if it increases confidence through evidence

Critique of TDD: "TDD, BDD, ATDD categorically do not replace testing, whatever their names may suggest." These are design techniques producing programmer-facing unit tests, not stakeholder-facing evidence.

Red flag: "A programmer's confidence in their own code is a notoriously poor indicator of quality." Developers have blind spots about their own work.

Application: Before writing a test, ask: (1) Which stakeholder? (2) What confidence? (3) What evidence? (4) Best way?
memories.context: Researching testing philosophy for PowerShell/Pester - foundational principle for ai-agents testing strategy

memories.title: Rico Mariani: 100% Unit Coverage as Ante (Baseline)
memories.content:
Rico Mariani (Microsoft): "In 2024, 100% unit-test coverage is only ante" - poker term meaning minimum bet to participate, not the end goal.

"100% unit-test coverage is absolutely positively not enough to get you to the finish line. You will need a lot of other kinds of things to round out the picture."

**Ante concept**:
- 100% unit coverage = baseline for "acceptance testing" (good enough to accept for real testing)
- Real testing = integration, E2E, performance, security, compliance, observability

Pragmatic philosophy: "At my core I am a pragmatist, I do things because they work, not because they look nice on paper."

**Three outcomes Mariani targets**:
1. Everything runs in a test at least once (enable sanitizers: ASAN, LEAKSAN, TSAN, UBSAN)
2. Error cases get exercised, however rare (attackers will force them to run)
3. Easy to spot code that still needs tests (100% is clear; 98% requires mental "oh but not that stuff" overhead)

**Value even without assertions**: "Suppose tests merely execute flows and verify nothing. Even then you still get tons of value. Tests run under ASAN/LEAKSAN/TSAN/UBSAN will catch memory leaks, data races, undefined behavior."

Context: Messenger, Microsoft Edge (high-security, privacy-sensitive, massive scale)
memories.context: Researching testing philosophy - provocative counter-argument to diminishing returns

memories.title: Coverage Diminishing Returns: Context-Dependent Truth
memories.content:
Two opposing views reconcile based on context:

**Rico Mariani**: "That unit-testing inherently suffers from diminishing returns is just flatly wrong."
- 1001st test not harder than 1000th (same infrastructure)
- Bugs found at all levels: "Down to a few blocks I'm thinking 'this is a waste' then I see it's wrong. This happens all the time."

**Industry Consensus**: 80% coverage sweet spot; 80-100% has diminishing returns.
- Google: 60% acceptable, 75% commendable, 90% exemplary
- Last 20% requires complex, hard-to-maintain tests

**Resolution - Both correct because**:
1. **Context**: Rico (Messenger/Edge: security-critical, PII, massive scale) vs. typical software
